title: Understanding the Spectrum
content:
# Understanding the Spectrum

The **waterfall display** and **FFT spectrum** are your primary tools for visualising radio signals. Learning to read them is essential.

## The FFT Spectrum

The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) converts time-domain samples into a frequency-domain view. It shows signal strength (dB) across a range of frequencies at one instant.

## The Waterfall

The waterfall is a scrolling spectrogram:
- **X-axis:** Frequency
- **Y-axis:** Time (newest at top)
- **Colour:** Signal strength (blue=quiet, yellow/red=strong)

## Reading Signals

| Pattern | Signal Type |
|---------|------------|
| Wide, constant band | FM broadcast (~200 kHz) |
| Thin constant line | Carrier/beacon |
| Intermittent blobs | Voice (push-to-talk) |
| Uniform rectangle | Digital data |
| Brief wideband pulse | Radar/burst |

## Key Concepts

- **Noise floor:** The background level where no signals exist
- **SNR:** Signal-to-Noise Ratio â€” how much a signal rises above the noise
- **Bandwidth:** How wide a signal is in Hz
- **Centre frequency:** The middle of your tuned range

steps.title: Opening the Waterfall
steps.content: In SignalForge, the waterfall is always visible on the main dashboard. You can also press '1' for a full-screen waterfall view.

steps.title: Identifying FM Stations
steps.content: Tune to the FM broadcast band (88-108 MHz). You'll see wide bands of colour â€” each one is a radio station. Stronger stations appear brighter.

steps.title: Finding Hidden Signals
steps.content: Zoom into quieter parts of the spectrum. Many signals are narrow and intermittent â€” walkie-talkies, pagers, IoT devices. The waterfall's time axis helps you spot brief transmissions.

quiz.question: What does the colour on a waterfall display represent?
quiz.explanation: Brighter/warmer colours indicate stronger signals. The exact colour scale varies but typically goes from blue (weak) to red/white (strong).

quiz.question: What is the noise floor?
options: The background level where no signals exist
quiz.explanation: The noise floor is the baseline level of random noise. Signals must rise above this floor to be detectable.
